com.littlesaints.protean.functions.streams

Class Try<T,R>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.littlesaints.protean.functions.streams.Try<T,R>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The input type in the function.
    R - The return type.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.function.Function<T,R>

    public class Try<T,R>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.function.Function<T,R>
     This is a functional substitute for an 'try-catch' construct as a lambda, especially when using java streams.
 It allows a cleaner way to specify a mapper to be invoked when an exception get raised, in a functional manner.

 The function wrapWithOptional(Try) can be used to create a function, that returns an Optional of the return Type, since there can be cases where there are no matching conditions provided to map a value.
 e.g. Configuring an 'try' condition without specifying the value mapper in an exception scenario, because one needs a return value.

 Usage:

 

    Arrays.stream(new String[]{"1", "2", "a", "3"})
        .map(i -> {
            try {
                return Integer.parseInt(i);
            } catch (Exception e) {
                return Integer.MIN_VALUE;
            }
        })
        .forEach(System.out::println);
 

 can be written as:

 
     Arrays.stream(new String[]{"1", "2", "a", "3"})
         .map(
             Try.<String, Integer> evaluate(Integer::parseInt)
                 .onFailure((string, exception) -> Integer.MIN_VALUE))
         .forEach(System.out::println);
 

 Note:
 - The use of 'finally' construct is also supported.
    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    Trial, If

        wrapWithOptional()

      • wrapWithOptional

        public Try<T,java.util.Optional<R>> wrapWithOptional()
         Create a Try function that returns an Optional.

 This is useful when the application doesn't want to handle  null directly but the code can return  null
 or there's no code mapped to 'onSuccess' or 'onFailure' construct.
        Returns:
        a copy of this 'Try' function.
